_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Upgraded reactor flex pieces and acid lines

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
MPM SILICONES
WATERFORD, NY

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

The following information can be found in Section A.1.0 of the MPMIslicones, LLC, Waterford Safety Manual, which is fully endorsed by facility managers.

ENVIRONMENTAL, HEALTH AND SAFETY (EHS) POLICY 
	
MPM Silicones is committed to achieving environmental, health and safety (EHS) excellence. This is the responsibility of both management and employees in all functions of the business. We strive to provide a safe and healthy working atmosphere and to avoid adverse impact to the environment and communities in 
which we do business. Our EHS process is expected to combine clear leadership by management, the participation of all employees and functions and the use of appropriate technology in developing, and distributing GE Silicones products and services. 

We will utilize PHA, Incident Investigation, MOC, PSSR, PSI and Training involvement processes in our Process Safety Management Program.  All employees have access to and/or are provided process safety information.  We actively involve employees in the development and implementation of Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures and Training, and other elements of the PSM Standard (OSHA 1910.119).  It is recognized that employees who are responsible for operating processes are the key resource in a successful Process Safety Program. 
We are accomplishing the above goals through:

* Making a clear and visible statement of our EHS Policy.

* Defining responsibilities, accountability, recognition and disciplinary actions.

* Exercising both management and employee involvement in EHS.

* By providing appropriate EHS training to all employees.   

* Performing on-going evaluations and revisions to EHS processes for lasting effectiveness and continuous improvement.

* Establishing procedures to effectively recognize, evaluate and control EHS hazards.

* Usin

g Six Sigma tools to help drive EHS performance excellence.


At MPM Silicones, we realize that our most valued assets are our employees. Both management and employees must consider themselves a team, working together to accomplish the common goal of a safe, healthful and environmentally sound workplace.

	

Description of facility and regulated substances:

MPM Silicones Waterford, located at 260 Hudson River Road in Saratoga County, New York, is a specialty chemical manufacturing facility that produces silicone intermediates and products.  This manufacturing facility is located on an 800-acre site adjacent to the Hudson River, where it has been in operation since 1947.  Currently, the facility has approximately 1,040 employees .  The facility uses an estimated 400 chemicals to produce over 1,000 intermediate products using approximately 90 different batch processes.  Through the conversion of silicon metal to silicone fluids and gums, GES supplies constituents that are used in the manufacture of over 2,000 consumer and industrial products, including oils, lubricants, adhesives, coatings, gums, sealants and rubber.

The MPM Silicones, Waterford Facility uses seven chemicals that are regulated under EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) in quantities above the reporting threshold.  Four of these are from the family of chemicals known as chlorosilanes.  These include methyltrichlorosilane, dimethyldichlorosilane, trimethylchlorosilane (regulated as toxic substances),and trichlorosilane (regulated as a flammable substance).  Other regulated toxic chemicals include methyl chloride and hydrochloric acid.  Hydrogen is the other flammable material physically present at the facility that is regulated by the RMP regulation.  Although the hydrogen storage is part of a stationary source not owned or operated by GES, GES carried out an offsite consequence analysis of this material because the hydrogen is physically located on GES' site and is connected by piping to GE

hat adequate resources are available to respond on-site and off-site to chemical emergencies.  As a result of the agreements, the GE Silicones emergency brigade has responded to many non-GE off-site chemical and other emergencies.  Recent emergency training drills, organized and directed by the GE Silicones emergency brigade, have included:
* A chemical release from one of our RMP scenarios in 2003 of the 008 tank.
* A table-top simulation of a WMD event  from a large chemical storage tank with representatives of local emergency response organizations in the Town of Waterford.

Ongoing training exercises are important to the GE emergency response organization and help prepare our partners in the community for emergency response in the unlikely event of a major industrial accident. 

MPM personnel have helped develop emergency preparedness plans for local communities.  In addition, they are members of local emergency planning and community emergency response groups.  We have provided training and equipment to our mutual aid partners. As consistent with the Saratoga County Emergency Plan, GE will work through the Waterford Police and Saratoga Emergency Management Office to communicate any appropriate actions to be taken by the public in the event of a chemical emergency.

Planned changes to improve safety:

The MPM Silicones Waterford facility has achieved recognition as an OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Star site.  VPP status is a way for OSHA to recognize facilities that go above and beyond compliance with safety regulations.  Only approximately 0.03% of work sites in the country have achieved VPP status.  

The VPP requires a commitment by the facility to continuous safety improvement.  MPM Silicones is committed to the VPP and is therefore continuously striving to improve the safety of the Waterford facility.

The facility has several projects and programs planned for the near future to improve our safety performance.  These include:
* Inve

stment in upgraded emergency lighting and safety shower equipment site-wide,
* Installation of new fall protection equipment at bulk loading stations throughout the site, and
* Focus on ergonomic injury mitigation through investment in material handling equipment and ergonomics and conditioning awareness training of operating personnel.
